Award.AwardTitle: Cosmic Origin of Matter: Nonequilibrium Field Theory and Inflationary Cosmology
Award.AbstractNarration: Present observations firmly support the notion that the early Universe underwent a short period of exponential) expansion known as inflation. The origin of matter is traced to the end of this inflationary era, when the primordial field that drives inflation transfers its energy into matter fields. This transfer is dramatic: it effectively models the hot Big Bang - and is believed to have occurred in at least two phases, known as preheating and reheating. The goal of this proposal is to address both the origin of matter and its excess over antimatter as inflation transitions into the hot Big Bang model. The PI plans to analyze in detail the nonperturbative dynamics of the preheating and reheating stages for a variety of models. . Based on this analysis, the PI hopes to propose several observational consequences of pre/reheating for different models, including: the number of e-folds or efficacy of the inflationary phase; the generation of net baryon number; and the production of a stochastic background of gravitational waves. The broader impact of the research is that the fundamental questions about the Universe addressed in this proposal are of great interest to wide ranging research groups and to the general public.. Apart from training his own graduate students, the PI is actively engaged in disseminating science to the general public through lectures, books, and TV documentaries. The PI has recently started a collaboration with Vermont's Montshire Museum of Science, to organize a series of public lectures to the local community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the greatest challenges of modern cosmology and particle physics is to explain the origin of matter in the Universe. How did the matter that makes galaxies, stars, and ultimately living beings originate in the primeval fireball described by the Big Bang model? Can we model the Big Bang as an explosive creation of matter? Modern cosmology teaches us that what we call the Big Bang is not really the "beginning," but a transition from an epoch when the universe expanded ultra fast (the inflationary epoch) to one when the expansion slowed down. This transition occurred when energy from what we call a primordial field (or fields) was transformed into ordinary particles. To understand this transition is one of the most interesting and difficult questions in modern theoretical physics.

Accordingly, in this project we developed powerful numerical codes and analytical techniques to model and describe the formation of material structures during the dramatic transition between the two cosmic epochs that marked the Big Bang. We divided our work into two main parts: first, the analytical study of configurations (energy lumps, really) formed due to the self-interactions of the fields that describe elementary particles of matter and their interactions. Second, we took this knowledge into an expanding universe and modeled numerically how these fields behave as the universe changes in time, in particular at the end of inflation.

Our analytical results were the first to explain a host of properties of these configurations, which before were only measured numerically. We found that objects known as "oscillons" (a name this PI created when he co-discovered this objects in 1994) can live for a surprisingly long time (that is, they don't decay away) due to a fine-tuned compromise between their attractive forces and their tendencies to disperse away, as waves would. Their properties, we believe, are ubiquitous in many other natural phenomena.

In our cosmological studies, we discovered something quite remarkable: the interactions between the fields are capable of creating complex material structures that survive for a very long time and that greatly affect the evolution of the universe. This result opens the door to a brand new area of research, the effects of such structures in cosmology and, in particular, in the transition between the two epochs that we call the Big Bang. Quite possibly, these structures played a crucial role in the evolution of the early universe. Excitingly, we also showed that similar structures emerge when symmetries are broken in Nature, a result that bridges between cosmology and high energy physics and many other areas of research, including condensed matter and the physics of fluids.
